channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Congo Rebels Killed 6 and Kidnapped 14, Group Says
item.description: A statement from the group blamed the Allied Democratic Forces, a rebel group with origins in neighboring Uganda.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Jordan Struggles Under a Wave of Syrian Refugees
item.description: Jordan’s leaders face appeals from an overwhelmed public and from European nations urging them to stop the Syrians from heading to the West.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS
item.media:description: Syrian refugees on the outskirts of Mafraq, Jordan, in July. Jordan is now home to more than 1.4 million Syrians, including over 600,000 refugees who have arrived since the beginning of the conflict in 2011, according to officials.

item.title: Russian Orthodox Church Blocks Funeral for Last of Romanov Remains
item.description: Despite mountains of evidence, the church says it doesn’t believe the remains are those of the last czar and his family.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cross at Gamina Yama, a mine where the murdered Romanovs were first buried.

item.title: Shabab Claims Plane Attack
item.description: A man who set off a bomb was sucked out of a Daallo Airlines plane through a hole when the blast ripped open the cabin in flight, officials said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Francis Admonishes Bishops in Mexico to ‘Begin Anew’
item.description: Speaking at Mexico City’s majestic Metropolitan Cathedral, the pope spared no criticism as he painted an almost biblical picture of a church seduced by power and money.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Pope Francis greeted supporters after a welcome ceremony at the National Palace in Mexico City, on Saturday.

item.title: Facing Allies’ Doubt, John Kerry Voices Confidence in Syria Cease-Fire
item.description: Mr. Kerry, the secretary of state, promised on Saturday to help close off the routes migrants are taking to Europe and warned Russia that its military efforts in Syria to support President Bashar al-Assad would ultimately fail.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, speaking at the Munich Security Conference on Saturday.

item.title: Medical Supplies Reach War-Torn City in Yemen
item.description: Many residents of Taiz, a city of 200,000 in the southwest of the country, say that the Houthi rebels have blocked aid from entering and have bombed civilian sites.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Britain Aims to Strengthen North’s Cities
item.description: Under a “Northern Powerhouse” plan, the government has pledged to build more roads and railways, invest in technology and research hubs, and even appeal to China’s development bank for funds.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Major renovation around Liverpool Football Club that is clearing slum areas and creating new housing.

item.title: Taliban, Using Humvees Stolen From Army, Attack Check Post
item.description: Four Afghan policemen and two soldiers were killed in the attack in Helmand Province, and eight others were wounded.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: War, Disease, Scandals: Slugging It Out in Sierra Leone’s Soccer Politics
item.description: Isha Johansen, the president of Sierra Leone’s soccer association, is one of just a handful of women in the world to have held such a post.
item.dc:creator: TOMMY TRENCHARD
item.media:description: Isha Johansen, the president of the Sierra Leone Football Association, at the FIFA Congress in Zurich last May.

item.title: Catholic Leaders Say Zika Doesn’t Change Ban on Contraception
item.description: After a period of saying little, bishops in Latin America are beginning to speak up and reassert the church’s opposition to birth control and abortion.
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: A Brazilian mother and her 5-month-old daughter with microcephaly. Experts are not yet sure whether Zika is the cause of a sudden surge in babies born in Brazil with the birth defect.

item.title: Pope and Russian Orthodox Leader Meet in Historic Step
item.description: As the pope approached the Russian patriarch, Francis was overheard to say, “Brother.” A moment later, he added, “Finally.”
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Falling Asleep to Grenades: Mexicans Tell Pope How They Live
item.description: Before Pope Francis’s arrival in Mexico, we asked readers there to tell us what he should know about their lives. We received more than 500 responses on Facebook.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Public phones were covered with images of Pope Francis on Thursday, a day before his arrival in Mexico City.

item.title: Rescue Efforts End in Taiwanese City Struck by Quake
item.description: Search crews on Saturday pulled the last of 114 bodies from the site of a 17-story complex that collapsed in the Feb. 6 quake in the city of Tainan.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Constant Tide of Migrants at Sea, and at Turkish Cemetery
item.description: Increased patrols and cold weather have done little to dissuade refugees fleeing war, and those who drown and are unclaimed are each given numbers and buried.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: North Korea Cancels Investigation Into Abductions of Japanese Citizens
item.description: The North halted its inquiry into the fate of Japanese said to have been kidnapped decades ago, retaliating for new sanctions imposed by Tokyo.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: North Korean and Japanese officials in Pyongyang in 2014, discussing the North’s investigation into the fate of Japanese citizens its agents were said to have abducted decades ago.

item.title: Q. and A.: Syrian War Could Turn on the Battle for Aleppo
item.description: Syrian government forces and their allies are besieging the rebel-held section of Aleppo to starve the rebels into submission.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Heavily damaged buildings in the Saif al Dawle neighborhood of Aleppo in 2012, when rebel groups seized its eastern half and the government responded with shelling.

item.title: Head of Sweden’s Karolinska Institute Quits Over Transplant Scandal
item.description: Anders Hamsten said he could no longer lead the the institute after accusations of medical misconduct against a former professor there.
item.dc:creator: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: U.S. Plans to Resume Commercial Flights to Cuba This Year
item.description: An agreement to be completed next week will allow American carriers to offer 20 flights per day to Havana and dozens more to other Cuban cities.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Many Asians Express Dismay and Frustration After Liang Verdict
item.description: In Asian enclaves of New York, residents objected to the guilty verdict of Officer Peter Liang, saying that he was a scapegoat because of his race.
item.dc:creator: SARAH MASLIN NIR and DAVID W. CHEN
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vendors in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, a neighborhood with a large Asian population. Many residents objected on Thursday to the guilty verdict for Officer Peter Liang, who is Chinese-American.
